{"step_by_step_thinking": "Benign intracranial hypertension, also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, is a condition characterized by increased intracranial pressure without any identifiable cause. The symptoms of benign intracranial hypertension are primarily related to increased pressure within the skull. Proptosis, which is the bulging of the eyes, can occur in some cases of benign intracranial hypertension due to increased pressure on the optic nerve. Normal size ventricles are typically seen in benign intracranial hypertension as there is no obstruction to the flow of cerebrospinal fluid. Headache is a common symptom of benign intracranial hypertension and is often described as a pulsating or throbbing pain.
